properties.media:imagetext:
SHANGHAI
APRIL 15, 1933.
Dear Family;
This is the first ciroular letter in a long time. I have been very busy
since the first of this month with the affairs of Ch ina National Aviation Corp. which
is the Chinese Aviation company purchased as of April first by Pan American. The line
is 55% owned by the Ministry of Communications and 45% by P.A.A. It runs from Shanghai
up the Yangstze River over 1000 miles to Chungking. Another lin e runs from Shanghai to
Peiping which is 800 miles by air north of here. A line which has been projected is the
one from here to Canton which is another 1000 miles to the south.
Last weekond I spent with the Minister of Communications and his wife at Hang-
chow, about 100 miles south of here. The party consisted also of a man named Wong who
is an adviser of the M. of C, Mr. Tai who is Managing Director of China National Aviatia
Co., and the Ministers little eight year old daughter. Sunday morning we visited the most
famous temple in all China. One of the outstanding attractions is a large beautifully
carved wall of the temple dedicated to the Whittemore children - at least it depicts
children asking fifty seven
different questions, dont know why there are fifty seven
questions but that is the number of carvings. The country around Hangchow is perfectly
beautiful and the roads fairly good. After a long drive we wound up at a Chinese restu-
raunt where we found some more guests - all Chinese. I was the only foreigner present.
We had sharks fins, rice wine, chicken soup and all the usual Chinese food and then the
real special treat - believ e it or not - live shrimps. The brought in a dish with a
cover over it. When the cover was raised a shrimp jumped right out on the table and one
of the gentlemen present grabbed said shrimp with his chop sticks and stowed him below.
Gosh how I wished brother Bill had seen that, The shrimps are soaked in or rather hot
rice wine is pored over the shrimps and they get very active. I knew that I would lose
a lot of face if I showed any weakness so just reached into the dish with my sticks got
hold of a shrimp who was not as active as some of the others and hoped that he wouldnt
holler "help". Lots of old residents out here have never been up against that experience
although they have all heard about it. Now my education is complete
except for snakes.
I hope to try them when I go to Canton where they are a speciality.
I really like the
Chinee "chow" as it is called out here. The cooking, like the dialect, is different in
each province.
Monday we went on an all day hike to a temple on the top of a mountain
about the hight of Buck Mt. but the climbing was not as hard. The climb was not very
pleasant because of the beggars who literally lined the path, but coming down we took a
small path which led down the other side of the Mountain and the walk was grand. The
whole mountain side one mass of flowers, white and various shades of pink ezelias ? with
other small bushs and thousands of wild flowers. The finest tea in the world is grown in
this section of China and brings one dollar Mex per ounce. We saw them picking it. aci
Bic
